A. ESTERUELAS, E. SOLA, L. A. ORO Departamento de Quimica Inorganica, Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Aragon, Universidad de Zaragoza, C.S.I.C. 50009 Saragossa (Spain) H. WERNER and U. MEYER Institut fur Anorganische Chemie der Uniuersitat Wurzburg Am Hubland, D-8700 Wurzburg (F.R.G.) (Received June 25, 1987; accepted October 27, 1987) The homogeneous catalytic reduction of ketones is of considerable interest in connection with industrially important reactions such as those involved in the oxo and aldox processes [1]. The RuCl2(PPh3)3 and RuHX(PPh3)3 (X = Cl, Br) complexes are active catalysts for reduction of ketones, both by molecular hydrogen [2 - 4] and by hydrogen transfer from appropriate organic donor molecules [5-8], such as isopropanol [8]. The rate of hydrogen transfer to ketones is frequently enhanced if a small quantity of potassium hydroxide is added to the system [6, 8]. However, to the best of our knowledge, no osmium compounds have been found active for the catalytic transfer of hydrogen from alcohols to ketones. Only very recently Sanchez-Delgado et al. have shown that the complex OsHBr(CO)(PPh3)3 is an active catalyst for the hydrogenation of carbonyl groups by molecular hydrogen [4, 9]. Some of us recently described the preparation and high reactivity of the complexes MHCl(CO)(PiPr3)2 (M = Ru, Os) [10]. In continuing this work, we were interested to explore the catalytic activity of these complexes in the reduction of cyclohexanone and acetophenone to the corresponding alcohols. Table 1 shows that the activity of MHCl(CO)(PiPr3)2 (M = Ru, Os), in the absence of cocatalysts, is rather poor; thus after 180 min the conversion is not more than 8% under nitrogen or hydrogen atmosphere. However, the addition of NaBH4 under hydrogen transfer conditions gives rise to an impor- tant increase in catalytic activity. In this context it is worth mentioning that the compounds MHCl(CO)(PiPr3)2 react with NaBH4 to give initially MH(i^2-H2BH2)(CO)(PiPr3)2 (M = Ru, Os) [10c]. Furthermore, some hydride tetrahydroborate complexes of d6 ions decompose in solution to give poly- hydrides of d4 ions [11-13]. For example, the complex OsH(l72-H2BH2)- (CO)(PiPr3)2 decomposes in methanol under reflux to give OsH4(CO)(P'Pr3)2 0304-5102/88/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands TABLE 1 Reduction of cyclohexanone and acetophenone catalysed by MHCHCO^P'Pra^ com- plexes Cocatalyst Atm Time mol cyclohexanol mol 1-phenylethanol (min) mol catalyst mol catalyst Ru Os Ru Os N2 180 8 5 7 1 H^ 180 5 7 4 2 KOH N2 5 61 15 86 45 60 32 77 16 180 67 89 37 KOH Hz 5 56 15 90 48 60 24 76 13 180 58 90 38 NaBH4 N2 5 59 15 95 60 24 82 13 180 58 95 37 Reaction conditions: [M] = 2.5 X 10~3 M, [sub]/[M] = 100, [cocat]/[M] = 5; solvent: propan-2-ol (vol = 8 ml); T = 83 C;P = 1 atm. Activation performed at 83 C over 1 h. "No hydrogen consumption was observed. [10c]. It is noteworthy that potassium hydroxide also acts as an appropriate cocatalyst under nitrogen or hydrogen atmosphere (Table 1). Most probably, the addition of KOH to the compounds MHCl(CO)(PiP^3)2 in isopropanol, under catalytic conditions, also leads to the formation of MH4(CO)(PiPr3)2 species. It has been reported that hydrogen transfer reactions from iso- propanol produce, via ^-abstraction, iridium polyhydrides [11,12,14]. Scheme 1 shows a possible mechanism for the catalytic reduction of ketones. As the complexes MH4(CO)(P'Pr3)2 are coordinatively saturated, activation most probably involves the loss of one hydrogen molecule per molecule of catalyst, to yield MH2(CO)(PiPr3)2 intermediates. A similar mechanism has recently been proposed by Halpern for the hydrogenation of cyclohexanone with RuH4(PPh3)3 [15]. Furthermore, 'H NMR studies on the related dihydride complex OsH2(CO)(PiPr3)3 [10c] show the easy dis- sociation of a phosphine group, and in methanol subsequent formation of the proposed tetrahydride complex OsH4(CO)(PlPr3)2. As shown in Scheme 1, we believe that the formation of acetone during the reaction involves an equilibrium between the metal-alkoxy intermediate (formed by hydrogen migration from the metal to the ketonic double bond) and a metal-isopropoxide intermediate. The isopropoxide species can give the coordinatively unsaturated metal dihydride by a ^-elimination process with subsequent formation of acetone. Accordingly, we have recently shown MmOCHRR'KCOXP-^l, Scheme 1. Proposed mechanism for the catalytic reduction of cyclohexanone and aceto- phenone by hydrogen transfer from isopropanol. that this pathway leads to IrHL; species, which are catalysts for hydrogen transfer from alcohols to cyclohexanone [16]. The studies reported in this letter reveal a higher activity of the ruthe- nium complexes relative to their osmium analogues. This observation could be tentatively assigned to the higher M H bond energies of third-row metals. Along this line, Crabtree and Hamilton have shown that some polyhydride complexes of transition metals could be considered as dihydrogen com- pounds; thus, MH4IJ3 complexes of the iron triad are really M(II) for Fe and Ru,butM(IV)forOs[17]. Other reduction reactions catalysed by the above-mentioned ruthenium and osmium complexes are reported in Table 2. The MHCUCO^P'I^^ compounds are poor catalysts for hydrogen transfer from isopropanol to styrene with NaBH4 as cocatalyst, but these complexes are active catalysts for the reduction of styrene with molecular hydrogen in 1,2-dichloroethane at 60 C. Under these conditions, the presence of NaBH4 or other cocatalysts is not necessary. Competitive reduction tests for cyclohexanone: styrene (1:1) with the catalysts show preferential reduction of cyclohexanone under hydrogen transfer conditions; however, under hydrogenation conditions the styrene is reduced exclusively. The C^C bond of phenylacetylene can also be selectively reduced under hydrogen transfer conditions. As the reactions progress, solutions become more strongly colored and catalytic activity is reduced. In this context, it is worth noting that the compounds MH(i?2- H2BH2)(CO)(P'Pr3)2 react with phenylacetylene in refluxing methanol to give very stable metal bis(alkynyl) complexes M(C2Ph)2(CO)(P'Pr3)2 TABLE 2 Other reactions catalysed by MHCUCOXP^ra)^ complexes M Cocat- Cone alyst tions li- T , ( C) Substrate (S) Tim( (h) ' mo mol < 1 of SH, of catalyst Selectivity Ru NaBH4 a 83 styrene 24 16.0 Ru NaBH4 a 83 cyclohexanone : 1 4.0 (ethylbenzene) 92.0d styrene (1:1) 44.0 (cyclohexanol) Ru b 60 styrene 4 83.0 Ru b 20 styrene 16 58.0 Ru b 60 cyclohexanone : 2 44.0 (ethylbenzene) styrene (1:1) 0.0 (cyclohexanol) 100.0e Ru NaBH4 " 83 phenylacetylene 19 6.0 (styrene) 0.0 (ethylbenzene) 100.0* Ru NaBH4 a 83 cyclohexanone : c 40.0 (cyclohexanol) acetophenone (1:1) 11.5 ( 1 -phenylethanol) 77.56 Os NaBH4 a Os NaBH4 a Os - b Os - b Os - b Os NaBH4 a Os NaBH4 a Os NaBH4 a 83 styrene 24 83 cyclohexanone: 24 styrene (1:1) 60 styrene l 20 styrene 16 60 cyclohexanone : 2 styrene (1:1) 83 phenylacetylene 4 83 phenylacetylene: 3 styrene (1:1) 83 cyclohexanone: 3 acetophenone (1:1) 7.0 - 6.0 (ethylbenzene) 25.0 (cyclohexanol) 80.0d 63.0 24.0 31.0 (ethylbenzene) 0.0 (cyclohexanol) 100.0e 23.0 (styrene) 0.0 (ethylbenzene) 100.0* 75.0 (styrene) 0.0 (ethylbenzene) 100^ 26.0 (cyclohexanol) 17.0 (1-phenylethanol) 60.08 "Hydrogen transfer conditions: [M] = 2.5 X 10-3 M; [sub]/[M] = 100; [NaBH4]/[M] = 5; activation period: 60 min; activation temperature: 83 C; solvent: propan-2-ol; atmo- sphere: N2. b Hydrogenation conditions: [M] = 2.5 X 10"3 M; [sub]/(M] = 100; activation period: 30 min; activation temperature: 25 C; solvent: 1,2-dichloroethane; atmosphere: Ha; PU = 1 atm.
